facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 118 of 1958 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 118 of 1958.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1958 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1594 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant was arrested on April 26, 1954 by the Sisamau Police for offences under sections 420, 482, 483, 485 and 486 of the Indian Penal Code.

issues.text: whether the proceedings were barred by s. 15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889

anchor.surface_text: the appellant filed an application before the Magistrate wherein he raised a preliminary objection that the proceedings were barred by s. 15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889  4 of 1889 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

issues.text: The contention of the appellant was that ... the proceedings should therefore be quashed as barred by limitation under s. 15 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant was that the offence was discovered on April 26, 1954, when he was arrested and the goods seized, and that, in consequence, the issue of process on July 22, 1955, was beyond the period of one year provided under s. 15 of the Act, and that the proceedings should therefore be quashed as barred by limitation.

issues.text: The point for decision is, when does a prosecution commence for purposes of s. 15 of the Act, whether on the date when the complaint is preferred, or when the process is issued thereon?

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision is, when does a prosecution commence for purposes of s. 15 of the Act, whether on the date when the complaint is preferred, or when the process is issued thereon? The word prosecution is not defined in the Act,

issues.text: what is the nature of the prosecution under s. 15 of the Act ?

anchor.surface_text: the date of presentation thereof that marks the commencement of the prosecution. Now, what is the nature of the prosecution under s. 15

arguments.claim: The proceedings are barred by limitation under s.15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act because the offence was discovered on April 26, 1954, and process was issued on July 22, 1955, beyond one year.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant was that the offence was discovered on April 26, 1954, when he was arrested and the goods seized, and that, in consequence, the issue of process on July 22, 1955, was beyond the period of one year provided under s. 15 of the Act, and that the proceedings should therefore be quashed as barred by limitation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges observed that there was a distinction between initiation of proceedings before the Magistrate and his taking companynizance of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Prosecution commences on presentation of complaint on May 26, 1954, within one year of discovery, as per general law and nature of the Act.

arguments.claim: Prosecution commenced when the complaint was presented on May 26, 1954, and as discovery was on April 26, 1954, proceedings are within time under s.15.

anchor.surface_text: By their judgment dated May 13, 1958, the learned Judges held that the prosecution commenced when the complaint was presented on May 26, 1954, and that as the discovery was on April 26, 1954, the proceedings were within time under s. 15 of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the learned Judges observed that there was a distinction between initiation of proceedings before the Magistrate and his taking companynizance of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with this view after detailed analysis.

arguments.claim: Under general law, a private prosecution commences when the complaint is preferred before the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Now, under the law and apart from statutory prescriptions, a prosecution commences, where it is at the instance of a private prosecutor, when the complaint is preferred. The position is thus stated in Halsburys Laws of England, Vol. X, 3rd Edn., p. 340, para. 630

arguments.claim: It is settled law that unless contrary in statute, private complaint presentation marks commencement of prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore settled law that unless there is something to the contrary in the statute, when a private complaint is presented it is the date of presentation thereof that marks the commencement of the prosecution.

arguments.claim: The prosecution under the Act is to provide speedy criminal remedy to protect trade mark owners, with limitation ensuring prosecutor's diligence, not court delays.

anchor.surface_text: Now, what is the nature of the prosecution under s. 15 of the Act ? It is relevant in this connection to refer to ss. 13 and 14... the law gives them the right to take the matter before the Criminal Courts, and prosecute the offenders, so as to enable them effectively ,and speedily to vindicate their rights.

arguments.claim: If complaint presented within one year of discovery, s.15 requirements satisfied; limitation operates against complainant for diligence.

anchor.surface_text: That means that if the complaint is presented within one year of such discovery, the requirements of s. 15 are satisfied. The period of limitation, it should be remembered, is intended to operate against the complainant and to ensure diligence on his part in prosecuting his rights, and not against the Court.

arguments.claim: In Ruppell v. Ponnuswami, prosecution barred only if complaint not filed within time; supports complaint filing as commencement.

anchor.surface_text: in Ruppell v. Ponnuswami Tewan 1 , the question rose whether a prosecution launched by the complainant in 1898... the complainant is required to resort to the Court within one year of the discovery of the offence if he is to have the benefit of proceeding under the Act.

arguments.claim: Prosecution commences only when process issued, as per Sheik Meeran Sahib, De Rozario, Golap Jan (malicious prosecution cases).

anchor.surface_text: In Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali 1 , De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee 2 and Golap Jan v. Bholanath Khettry 3 cited by the appellant, the question was whether an action for damages for malicious prosecution

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ey may be described as a prosecution the test is whether such proceedings have reached a stage at which damage to the plaintiff results. Vide also Ram

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as malicious prosecution tort requires process for damage stage; irrelevant to limitation commencement under Act.

arguments.claim: No prosecution until process issued, as per R.R. Chari v. State of UP.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in R. R. Chari v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 1 was relied on by the appellant as showing that until process was issued, there was no prosecution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 22, 1947, and that therefore there was numberprosecution on the date of the arrest. But here, we are dealing with a private companyplaint, and as poi

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: special police arrest under Corruption Act vs private complaint under CrPC s.190(1)(a) where cognizance on receipt.

arguments.claim: Distinction between initiation and cognizance under CrPC ss.200,202 means no prosecution till process, per Gopal Marwari.

anchor.surface_text: considering ss. 200 and 202 of the Criminal Procedure Code, the learned Judges observed that there was a distinction between initiation of proceedings

court_response_anchor.surface_text: our opinion, does number assist the appellant number does the decision in Gopal Marwari v. King-Emperor  2 . There, companysidering ss. 200 and 202 o

arguments.court_reasoning: Not the question here; s.15 requires only complaint within time for private prosecutor.

arguments.claim: Under CrPC s.190(1)(a), Magistrate takes cognizance on receipt of private complaint, marking prosecution start.

anchor.surface_text: s. 190 1 a of the Criminal Procedure Code would apply to such cases, and the Magistrate must be held to have taken cognizance when the complaint was received.

holdings.text: unless there is something to the contrary in the statute, when a private complaint is presented it is the date of presentation thereof that marks the commencement of the prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore settled law that unless there is something to the contrary in the statute, when a private complaint is presented it is the date of presentation thereof that marks the commencement of the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General position under law stated in Halsbury's Laws of England; settled law for private prosecutions apart from statutory exceptions.

holdings.text: if the complaint is presented within one year of such discovery, the requirements of s. 15 are satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: That means that if the complaint is presented within one year of such discovery, the requirements of s. 15 are satisfied. The period of limitation, it should be remembered, is intended to operate against the complainant and to ensure diligence on his part in prosecuting his rights, and not against the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limitation ensures prosecutor's diligence; derived from purpose of Act providing speedy remedy and Ruppell v. Ponnuswami.

holdings.text: s. 190 1 a of the Criminal Procedure Code would apply to such cases, and the Magistrate must be held to have taken cognizance when the complaint was received.

anchor.surface_text: s. 190 1 a of the Criminal Procedure Code would apply to such cases, and the Magistrate must be held to have taken cognizance when the complaint was received.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing R.R. Chari; private complaints under CrPC differ from special police cases under Corruption Act.

holdings.text: all that is-required is that a private prosecutor should prefer this complaint within one year of the discovery of the offence, and if that is done, the bar under that section cannot apply.

anchor.surface_text: on the language of s. 15 of the Act, which is what we are concerned with in this appeal, all that is-required is that a private prosecutor should prefer this complaint within one year of the discovery of the offence, and if that is done, the bar under that section cannot apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.15; rejects need for process issuance within limitation period.

holdings.text: the proceedings are not barred by s. 15 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the decision of the learned Judges of the Court below that the proceedings are not barred by s. 15 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies commencement rule to facts: complaint on May 26, 1954 within one year of discovery on April 26, 1954; agrees with lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: in Ruppell v. Ponnuswami Tewan  1 , the question rose whether a prosecution launched by the companyplainant in 1898 in respect of goods sold and marked with what was alleged to be, a companynterfeit trade mark in 1893 was in time.

precedents.cited_proposition: Prosecution under Prevention of Corruption Act commences when Magistrate takes cognizance upon complaint, not upon arrest

anchor.surface_text: That means that if the complaint is presented within one year of such discovery, the requirements of s. 15 are satisfied.
